tweets.content: Just noticed AI adoption in enterprise SaaS has hit inflection point. The teams building here early will have 10x advantage in market share.
Excited to announce our investment in CloudFlow! They're solving infrastructure complexity with a modern control plane. Welcome to the team!
Thesis: The next generation of climate tech companies will be built on principles of distributed energy and real-time optimization. Early teams thinking about this will win.
To founders raising Series A: Focus on unit economics before anything else. Every successful founder I know nailed this first.
Interesting trend: More early-stage founders are choosing technical co-founders over MBA co-founders. This will reshape how we evaluate founding teams.
Founders: How are you thinking about customer acquisition cost as you scale into new markets? Curious what's working.
New data: Companies that invest in developer experience see 3x improvement in hiring velocity. This is 3x growth from 18 months ago.
Lesson from 15 years investing in infrastructure: The winners understand regulatory landscapes before they build. The teams who do this early win.
Noticing a pattern: Every successful fintech founder I've backed spent time working inside traditional finance first. This context matters.
Led Series B round for DataFlow. Impressed by the founding team's ability to ship fast while maintaining code quality. Rare combination.
Why B2B SaaS is the most undervalued segment right now: (1) Recurring revenue, (2) Net negative churn, (3) Predictable growth curves. Here's our thesis...
The mistake I see most founders make: Building for product-market fit instead of building with customers. Start with customer feedback loops first.
4 out of 5 recent Series A pitches in AI are solving the same problem. The best ones are focused on vertical-specific applications.
To founders in crypto: What's the biggest bottleneck you're facing right now? DMs open - genuinely curious what problems need solving.
85% of founders now use AI tools for customer communication. This is 5x growth from 12 months ago. Early advantage went to those who adopted early.
The thing nobody tells you about seed funding: The relationships you build matter more than the check size. Build for long-term partnership.
Seeing a resurgence in vertical SaaS. Companies that deeply understand their specific industry will dominate horizontal players.
Thrilled to lead the seed round for Nexus! Building the infrastructure layer for the next generation of AI applications.
Unpopular opinion: API-first products will outperform UI-first products over the next 5 years. Here's why the shift is inevitable...
To founders building in a crowded space: Your competitive advantage comes from execution speed and customer obsession, not the idea.
Interesting shift: More founders are choosing go-to-market hires before product hires. This signals market-first thinking over tech-first.
To deep tech founders: How long from first customer to product-market fit in your space? DMs open - tracking this metric for pattern matching.
Fascinating stat: Seed-stage companies with female founders outperform on retention metrics by 23%. Quality teams win.
After backing 50+ founders: The ones who win never ask permission. They ship, learn, iterate. Momentum beats perfection.
The next unicorn will be built in an industry nobody is currently betting on. Where will it come from?
Proud to announce Catalyst Ventures' investment in StrideTech! Disrupting enterprise mobility with AI-driven logistics.
My thesis on remote-first companies: Those built natively remote will scale faster than traditional orgs transitioning to remote. Structural advantage.
Advice to first-time founders: Hire slow, fire fast. The wrong hire compounds. The right hire multiplies.
Trend alert: Enterprise is finally paying attention to developer experience. Security and speed are now table stakes.
To healthcare founders: What's preventing adoption of your solution? Is it technical, regulatory, or cultural? Let's talk.
60% of venture-backed software companies have adopted PLG (product-led growth). Up from 15% three years ago.
Key insight from backing 20 AI companies: The moat isn't the model, it's the data and user network. Build defensible advantages.
B2B2C might be the strongest GTM for horizontal SaaS. You get both enterprise defensibility and consumer scale.
Excited to back Aurora Labs' Series A! Solving supply chain visibility with real-time IoT data. Massive TAM ahead.
Theory: The companies that win in Web3 will be those that solve real coordination problems, not those chasing token narratives.
To first-time founders: Your board is there to help. Be honest about challenges early. The best boards catch issues before they become crises.
Pattern: Top founders are increasingly building in adjacent markets after their first exit. They understand moats.
To operations founders: How are you thinking about international expansion? Is it worth the complexity in year 1?
New benchmark: Top SaaS companies have CAC payback of 8 months or less. Anything longer signals inefficient go-to-market.
After 25 years in VC: The founders who succeed aren't the smartest in the room. They're the ones most obsessed with solving the problem.
Infrastructure-as-code is eating infrastructure. Every company building infrastructure has 2x higher valuations than SaaS peers.
Thrilled to co-lead Prism AI's Series B! Building generalist AI agents for enterprise workflows. The future is agentic.
Conviction: The winners in AI won't be LLM companies. They'll be domain experts who apply LLMs to specific verticals.
Advice: Never raise more money than you need for 18 months of runway. Scarcity breeds discipline and speed.
Observing: Top engineers are now evaluating opportunities based on learning potential, not just compensation. Talent market shifting.
To data infrastructure founders: What's your biggest customer acquisition challenge? Is it sales, product-market fit, or something else?
Statistic: Companies using AI for sales have 18% higher win rates. ROI is clear. Early adopters have sustainable advantage.
What I've learned: The best companies solve problems that get harder, not easier. Moats come from compounding difficulty.
The next wave of fintech will be built on embedded finance. Companies are realizing they need payments native to their workflow.
We're investing in Atlas' Series A! Building the next generation of procurement tools for enterprise. Massive TAM.
